front.title: Usage and Applicatbility of Link State Vector Routing in Data Centers

abstract.t: This document discusses the usage and applicability of Link State Vector Routing (LSVR) extensions in the CLOS architecture of Data Center Networks. The document is intended to provide a simplified guide for the deployment of LSVR extensions.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document complements by discussing the applicability of the technology in a simple and fairly common deployment scenario, which is described in .
After describing the deployment scenario, will describe the reasons for BGP modifications for such deployments.
Once the control plane routing protocol requirements are described, will cover the LSVR protocol enhancements to BGP to meet these requirements and their applicability to Data Center CLOS networks.

section.title: Recommended Reading
section.t: This document assumes knowledge of existing data center networks and data center network topologies . This document also assumes knowledge of data center routing protocols like BGP , BGP-SPF . OSPF , as well as, data center layer-2 link layer protocols like LLDP and BFD .

section.title: Common Deployment Scenario
section.t: Within a Data Center, a common network design to interconnect servers is done using the CLOS topology . section.title: Justification for BGP modifications
section.t: Many data centers use BGP as a routing protocol to create an overlay as well as an underlay network for their CLOS Topologies to simplify layer 3 routing . However, BGP is a path vector routing protocol Since it does not have a way for creating a topology, it uses hop-by-hop EBGP peering to facilitate hop-by-hop routing for the creating underlay network and for resolving any overlay nexthops. The hop-by-hop BGP peering imposes several restrictions within a CLOS. It severly prohibits a deployment of Route Reflectors/Route Controllers as the EBGP peerings are inline with the data path. The BGP best path algorithm is prefix based and it prevents announcements of prefixes to other BGP speakers unless the best path is executed for the prefix. These restrictions significantly delay the overall convergence of the underlay network within a CLOS.

The LSVR SPF modifications allow BGP to overcome these limitations. Furthermore, using the NLRI format of allows SPF to be computed on BGP LSVR data easily as facilicates announcement of node, link, and prefix information.

section.title: LSVR Applicabity to CLOS Networks
section.t: With the BGP SPF extensions , the BGP best path computation and route computation are replaced with OSPF-like algorithms both to determine whether an BGP-LS NLRI has changed and needs to be readvertised and to compute the routing domain. These modifications will significantly improve convergence of the underlay while affording the operational benefits of a single routing protocol .

Since every router in the BGP SPF domain will have a complete view of the topology, BGP sessions are not required on every link in the data center fabric as with the hop-by-hop peering model described in . Rather, protocols such as BFD can be used to determine the availability links and switches in the data center fabric. Consequently, the BGP session topology can be much more sparse than the data center fabric topology and can utilize a BGP route reflector hierarchy with the desired level of redundancy.

Data center controllers typically require visibility to the BGP topology to compute traffic-engineered paths. These controllers learn the topology and other relevant information via a BGP-LS address family which is totally independent of the underlay address families (usually IPv4/IPv6 unicast). Furthermnore, in traditional BGP underlays, all BGP routers will need to advertise their BGP-LS information independently. With the BGP SPF extensions, controllers can learn the topology using the same BGP advertisements used to compute the underlay routes. Furthermore, these data center controllers can avail the convergence advantages of the BGP SPF extensions. The placement of controllers could be outside of the forwarding path or within the forwarding path.

Alternatively, as each and every router in the BGP SPF domain will have a complete view view of the topology, the operator can also choose to configure BGP sessions in hop-by-hop peering model described in along with BFD . In doing so, while the hop-by-hop peering model lacks inherent benifits of the controller based model, BGP updates need not be serialized by BGP bestpath algorithm in either of these models. This helps overall network convergence.

section.title: Usage of LSVR SAFI
section.t: BGP SPF extensions defines a new BGP SAFI for for announcement of BGP SPF routes. The NLRI format and its associated attributes follows the format of BGP-LS for facilitate node, link and prefix annoucements. Whether the peering model within a CLOS follows hop-by-hop peering described in or any controller based peering, an operator can exchange BGP SPF SAFI routes over the BGP peering by simply configuring BGP SPF SAFI between the necessary BGP speakers.

BGP SPF SAFI can also co-exist with BGP IP Unicast SAFI which could exchange overlapping IP routes. The routes received by these SAFIs are evaluated, stored and announced seperately according to the rules of . The tie-breaking of route installation is a matter of local policies and preference to the operator and their network.
Finally as the BGP SPF peering is done following the procedures described in , all the existing tranport security mechanisms including are made available for BGP SPF SAFI.
